title: Add template support for issue creation
description:
Support creating issues from predefined templates to streamline common workflows like epics, bug reports, or feature proposals.

Example usage:
  bd create --from-template epic "Phase 3 Features"
  bd create --from-template bug "Login failure"
  bd template list
  bd template create epic

Templates should include:
- Pre-filled description structure
- Suggested priority and type
- Common labels
- Design/acceptance criteria sections

Implementation notes:
- Store templates in .beads/templates/ directory
- Support YAML or JSON format
- Ship with built-in templates (epic, bug, feature)
- Allow custom project-specific templates

title: Add label-based filtering to bd ready command
description:
Allow filtering ready work by labels to help organize work by sprint, week, or category.

Example usage:
  bd ready --label week1-2
  bd ready --label frontend,high-priority

This helps teams organize work into batches and makes it easier for agents to focus on specific categories of work.

Implementation notes:
- Add --label flag to ready command
- Support comma-separated labels (AND logic)
- Should work with existing ready work logic (unblocked issues)

title: Clarify JSONL size bounds with multi-repo
description:
The contributor-workflow-analysis.md states (line 226): 'Keep beads.jsonl small enough for agents to read (<25k)'

With multi-repo hydration, it's unclear whether this bound applies to:
- Each individual JSONL file (likely intention)
- The total hydrated size across all repos (unclear)
- Both (most conservative)

Clarification needed because:
- VC monitors .beads/issues.jsonl size to stay under limit
- With multi-repo, VC needs to know if each additional repo also has 25k limit
- Agents reading hydrated data need to know total size bounds
- Performance characteristics depend on total vs per-repo limits

Example scenario:
- Primary repo: 20k JSONL
- Planning repo: 15k JSONL
- Total hydrated: 35k
Is this acceptable or does it violate the <25k principle?
acceptance_criteria:
- Documentation explicitly states size bound applies per-repo or total
- Rationale explained (why that bound matters)
- Guidance for monitoring size with multi-repo
- If total bound exists, formula provided (e.g., sum of all repos <25k)

title: Add mermaid output format for bd dep tree
description:
Add visual dependency graph output using Mermaid format for better visualization of issue relationships.

Example usage:
  bd dep tree --format mermaid <issue-id>
  bd dep tree --format mermaid bd-42 > graph.md

This would output Mermaid syntax that can be rendered in GitHub, documentation sites, or Mermaid live editor.

Implementation notes:
- Add --format flag to dep tree command
- Support 'text' (default) and 'mermaid' formats
- Mermaid graph should show issue IDs, titles, and dependency types
- Consider using flowchart LR or graph TD syntax

title: Clarify exclusive lock protocol compatibility with multi-repo
description:
The contributor-workflow-analysis.md proposes per-repo file locking (Decision #7) using flock on JSONL files. However, VC (a downstream library consumer) uses an exclusive lock protocol (vc-195, requires Beads v0.17.3+) that allows bd daemon and VC executor to coexist.

Need to clarify:
- Does the proposed per-repo file locking work with VC's existing exclusive lock protocol?
- Do library consumers like VC need to adapt their locking logic?
- Can multiple repos be locked atomically for cross-repo operations?

Context: contributor-workflow-analysis.md lines 662-681
acceptance_criteria:
- Documentation explicitly states compatibility or incompatibility with existing lock protocols
- If incompatible, migration path is documented for library consumers
- If compatible, example showing coexistence is provided

title: Add performance benchmarks for multi-repo hydration
description:
The contributor-workflow-analysis.md asserts sub-second queries (line 702) and describes smart caching via file mtime tracking (Decision #4, lines 584-618), but doesn't provide concrete performance benchmarks.

VC's requirement (from VC feedback section):
- Executor polls GetReadyWork() every 5-10 seconds
- Queries must be sub-second (ideally <100ms)
- Smart caching must avoid re-parsing JSONLs on every query

Suggested performance targets to validate:
- File stat overhead: <1ms per repo
- Hydration (when needed): <500ms for typical JSONL (<25k)
- Query (from cache): <10ms
- Total GetReadyWork(): <100ms (VC's requirement)

Also test at scale:
- N=1 repo (baseline)
- N=3 repos (typical)
- N=10 repos (edge case)

These benchmarks are critical for library consumers like VC that run automated polling loops.
acceptance_criteria:
- Performance benchmark suite created for multi-repo hydration
- Benchmarks cover file stat, hydration, and query times
- Tests at N=1, N=3, N=10 repo scales
- Results documented in contributor-workflow-analysis.md
- Performance targets met or issues filed for optimization

title: Add guidance for self-hosting projects
description:
The contributor-workflow-analysis.md is optimized for OSS contributors making PRs to upstream projects. However, it doesn't address projects like VC that use beads for their own development (self-hosting).

Self-hosting projects differ from OSS contributors:
- No upstream/downstream distinction (they ARE the project)
- May run automated executors (not just humans)
- In bootstrap/early phase (stability matters)
- Single team/owner (not multiple contributors with permissions)

Guidance needed on:
- When self-hosting projects should stay single-repo (default, recommended)
- When they should adopt multi-repo (team planning, multi-phase dev)
- How automated executors should handle multi-repo (if at all)
- Special considerations for projects in bootstrap phase

Examples of self-hosting projects: VC (building itself with beads), internal tools, pet projects
acceptance_criteria:
- Section added: 'For Projects Using Beads for Self-Hosting'
- Clear guidance on when to stay single-repo vs adopt multi-repo
- Recommendations for automated executor behavior with multi-repo
- Bootstrap phase considerations documented
